snippet: Every March at the National People’s Congress in China’s capital is an elaborate display of multiparty cooperation that critics call a sham.
abstract: China's eight non-Communist parties, largely invisible most of the year, meet in Beijing for yearly elaborate display of multiparty cooperation that critics say is sham; so-called democratic parties, which are managed and financed by Communist Party, provide means of deflecting criticism of China as single-party dictatorship and absorbing segments of society that could one day form organized opposition.

byline.contributor: Patrick Zuo and Shi Da contributed research.

lead_paragraph: Every March at the National People’s Congress in China’s capital is an elaborate display of multiparty cooperation that critics call a sham.

headline.seo: China’s Non-Communist Parties Lend an Air of Pluralism
headline.main: Non-Communist Parties Lend China an Air of Pluralism, Without the Mess
headline.print_headline: Non-Communist Parties Lend China an Air of Pluralism, Without the Mess
